author: HCAndersen
text: THE flax was in full bloom; it had pretty little blue flowers as delicate as the wings of a moth, or even more so.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sun shone, and the showers watered it; and this was just as good for the flax as it is for little children to be washed and then kissed by their mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: They look much prettier for it, and so did the flax.

author: HCAndersen
text: "People say that I look exceedingly well," said the flax, "and that I am so fine and long that I shall make a beautiful piece of linen.

author: HCAndersen
text: How fortunate I am; it makes me so happy, it is such a pleasant thing to know that something can be made of me.

author: HCAndersen
text: How the sunshine cheers me, and how sweet and refreshing is the rain; my happiness overpowers me, no one in the world can feel happier than I am."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, yes, no doubt," said the fern, "but you do not know the world yet as well as I do, for my sticks are knotty;" and then it sung quite mournfully-

author: HCAndersen
text: "Snip, snap, snurre, Basse lurre: The song is ended."

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, it is not ended," said the flax.

author: HCAndersen
text: "To-morrow the sun will shine, or the rain descend.

author: HCAndersen
text: I feel that I am growing.

author: HCAndersen
text: I feel that I am in full blossom.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am the happiest of all creatures."

author: HCAndersen
text: Well, one day some people came, who took hold of the flax, and pulled it up by the roots; this was painful; then it was laid in water as if they intended to drown it; and, after that, placed near a fire as if it were to be roasted; all this was very shocking.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We cannot expect to be happy always," said the flax; "by experiencing evil as well as good, we become wise."

author: HCAndersen
text: And certainly there was plenty of evil in store for the flax.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was steeped, and roasted, and broken, and combed; indeed, it scarcely knew what was done to it.

author: HCAndersen
text: At last it was put on the spinning wheel.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Whirr, whirr," went the wheel so quickly that the flax could not collect its thoughts.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, I have been very happy," he thought in the midst of his pain, "and must be contented with the past;" and contented he remained till he was put on the loom, and became a beautiful piece of white linen.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the flax, even to the last stalk, was used in making this one piece.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, this is quite wonderful; I could not have believed that I should be so favored by fortune.

author: HCAndersen
text: The fern was not wrong with its song of

author: HCAndersen
text: 'Snip, snap, snurre, Basse lurre.'

author: HCAndersen
text: But the song is not ended yet, I am sure; it is only just beginning.

author: HCAndersen
text: How wonderful it is, that after all I have suffered, I am made something of at last; I am the luckiest person in the world- so strong and fine; and how white, and what a length!

author: HCAndersen
text: This is something different to being a mere plant and bearing flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then I had no attention, nor any water unless it rained; now, I am watched and taken care of.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every morning the maid turns me over, and I have a shower-bath from the watering-pot every evening.

author: HCAndersen
text: Yes, and the clergyman's wife noticed me, and said I was the best piece of linen in the whole parish.

author: HCAndersen
text: I cannot be happier than I am now."

author: HCAndersen
text: After some time, the linen was taken into the house, placed under the scissors, and cut and torn into pieces, and then pricked with needles.

author: HCAndersen
text: This certainly was not pleasant; but at last it was made into twelve garments of that kind which people do not like to name, and yet everybody should wear one.

author: HCAndersen
text: "See, now, then," said the flax; "I have become something of importance.

author: HCAndersen
text: This was my destiny; it is quite a blessing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I shall be of some use in the world, as everyone ought to be; it is the only way to be happy.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am now divided into twelve pieces, and yet we are all one and the same in the whole dozen.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is most extraordinary good fortune."

author: HCAndersen
text: Years passed away, and at last the linen was so worn it could scarcely hold together.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It must end very soon," said the pieces to each other; "we would gladly have held together a little longer, but it is useless to expect impossibilities."

author: HCAndersen
text: And at length they fell into rags and tatters, and thought it was all over with them, for they were torn to shreds, and steeped in water, and made into a pulp, and dried, and they knew not what besides, till all at once they found themselves beautiful white paper.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, now, this is a surprise; a glorious surprise too," said the paper.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am now finer than ever, and I shall be written upon, and who can tell what fine things I may have written upon me.

author: HCAndersen
text: This is wonderful luck!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And sure enough the most beautiful stories and poetry were written upon it, and only once was there a blot, which was very fortunate.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then people heard the stories and poetry read, and it made them wiser and better; for all that was written had a good and sensible meaning, and a great blessing was contained in the words on this paper.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I never imagined anything like this," said the paper, "when I was only a little blue flower, growing in the fields.

author: HCAndersen
text: How could I fancy that I should ever be the means of bringing knowledge and joy to man?

author: HCAndersen
text: I cannot understand it myself, and yet it is really so.

author: HCAndersen
text: Heaven knows that I have done nothing myself, but what I was obliged to do with my weak powers for my own preservation; and yet I have been promoted from one joy and honor to another.

author: HCAndersen
text: Each time I think that the song is ended; and then something higher and better begins for me.

author: HCAndersen
text: I suppose now I shall be sent on my travels about the world, so that people may read me.

author: HCAndersen
text: It cannot be otherwise; indeed, it is more than probable; for I have more splendid thoughts written upon me, than I had pretty flowers in olden times.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am happier than ever."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the paper did not go on its travels; it was sent to the printer, and all the words written upon it were set up in type, to make a book, or rather, many hundreds of books; for so many more persons could derive pleasure and profit from a printed book, than from the written paper; and if the paper had been sent around the world, it would have been worn out before it had got half through its journey.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is certainly the wisest plan," said the written paper; "I really did not think of that.

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall remain at home, and be held in honor, like some old grandfather, as I really am to all these new books.

author: HCAndersen
text: They will do some good.

author: HCAndersen
text: I could not have wandered about as they do.

author: HCAndersen
text: Yet he who wrote all this has looked at me, as every word flowed from his pen upon my surface.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am the most honored of all."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the paper was tied in a bundle with other papers, and thrown into a tub that stood in the washhouse.

author: HCAndersen
text: "After work, it is well to rest," said the paper, "and a very good opportunity to collect one's thoughts.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I am able, for the first time, to think of my real condition; and to know one's self is true progress.

author: HCAndersen
text: What will be done with me now, I wonder?

author: HCAndersen
text: No doubt I shall still go forward.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have always progressed hitherto, as I know quite well."

author: HCAndersen
text: Now it happened one day that all the paper in the tub was taken out, and laid on the hearth to be burnt.

author: HCAndersen
text: People said it could not be sold at the shop, to wrap up butter and sugar, because it had been written upon.

author: HCAndersen
text: The children in the house stood round the stove; for they wanted to see the paper burn, because it flamed up so prettily, and afterwards, among the ashes, so many red sparks could be seen running one after the other, here and there, as quick as the wind.

author: HCAndersen
text: They called it seeing the children come out of school, and the last spark was the schoolmaster.

author: HCAndersen
text: They often thought the last spark had come; and one would cry, "There goes the schoolmaster;" but the next moment another spark would appear, shining so beautifully.

author: HCAndersen
text: How they would like to know where the sparks all went to!

author: HCAndersen
text: Perhaps we shall find out some day, but we don't know now.

author: HCAndersen
text: The whole bundle of paper had been placed on the fire, and was soon alight.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ugh," cried the paper, as it burst into a bright flame; "ugh."

author: HCAndersen
text: It was certainly not very pleasant to be burning; but when the whole was wrapped in flames, the flames mounted up into the air, higher than the flax had ever been able to raise its little blue flower, and they glistened as the white linen never could have glistened.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the written letters became quite red in a moment, and all the words and thoughts turned to fire.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I am mounting straight up to the sun," said a voice in the flames; and it was as if a thousand voices echoed the words; and the flames darted up through the chimney, and went out at the top.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then a number of tiny beings, as many in number as the flowers on the flax had been, and invisible to mortal eyes, floated above them.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were even lighter and more delicate than the flowers from which they were born; and as the flames were extinguished, and nothing remained of the paper but black ashes, these little beings danced upon it; and whenever they touched it, bright red sparks appeared.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The children are all out of school, and the schoolmaster was the last of all," said the children.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was good fun, and they sang over the dead ashes,-

author: HCAndersen
text: "Snip, snap, snurre, Basse lure: The song is ended."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the little invisible beings said, "The song is never ended; the most beautiful is yet to come."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the children could neither hear nor understand this, nor should they; for children must not know everything.
